The institution will now be able to begin new exhibitions and programming at the Lantern Arts Center on Long Island City, Queens, on March 7, and will also begin a series of garden tours, events, and other programming that will run concurrently across the two locations.“We are making a concerted effort to minimize disruption to our guests, our traveling gallery, and our curators, and are planning to roll out new programs with a view to maximizing the health and well-being of our surrounding communities,” said Michael Guggenheim, the museum’s director. The Museum of Contemporary Art (MoCA) in Los Angeles is urging creatives from around the world to participate in the “March for Science.” The event, which will take place on Saturday, March 28, will honor the March for Science, a global movement of artists and scientists who have pledged to donate their bodies and scientific materials for scientific research. The March for Science is sponsored by the Institute of Biomedical Science at the University of California, Los Angeles, the National Center for Biotechnology Information, the National Gene Bank, and the National Cancer Institute. The deadline for artworks donated is April 22.The museum said: “The Museum of Contemporary Art is currently reviewing the invitation to artists from around the world to participate in the March for Science, which will be held at MoCA in 2021. We hope that this opportunity will give you an insight into how we think about science and art and how we can think about how we can change our world. We are all at the same time concerned with protecting and celebrating life and protecting the environment, and we hope that this invitation will help you to think about how we can be more connected to life and to the world in general.�
